results.title: Fly through visualisations
results.brief_description: Collection of nine fly throughs using 3D visualisations of the Cinemedia complex at Federation Square. Some show plaza , most move from plaza through to ground floor and escalators.

results.title: Fire of time
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Urban development in Barcelona has all but destroyed the once vibrant Barrio Chino where the nights were days and the days were long. This is an evocative film shot through windows, on street corners and in small rooms. People, clouds, and the swift tail lights of cars glide past and through, as fleeting traces of the passage of time. And as this one working-class Red Light district is transformed and changed by the process of gentrification, the former residents appear as ghosts, their prescence - as graffiti, as shadows - a reminder of the real history of the city. Larger forces cause buildings and neighbourhoods to vanish but they are rebuilt again in memories, worn photographs and in light. Adam Cohen’s handling of light gives people the substance of phantoms and their passages through the half deserted streets evoke Eliot, Proust, and Chris Marker. Sounds of this world are orchestrated with cello, organ and guitar to form a profoundly beautiful work about memory, longing and loss.

results.title: Screen Gallery scaling visualisation
results.brief_description: Two visualisations. The first, the projected opening on May 9th, 2001 for the Cinemedia Screen Gallery. Includes 18 projectors, 16 plasma screens, 16 TFT screens and 24 TFT kiosks. The second on May 9th, 2003 includes 250 screens. Both show moving image clips projected onto different types and sizes of screens, and give a sense of how the screen gallery at Federation Sqaure will look and feel.

results.title: Ross Gibson interview Tape #2
results.brief_description:
Interview Date: 22nd March, 2002.
Ross Gibson discusses a number of issues relating to the curatorial background and philosophy of assembling the ACMI collection. Ross also discusses the approach taken by ACMI staff to generating content and assembling the collection with the viewer’s experience in mind. Other topics of discussion relate to the genesis of Ross’ involvement with the project, an overview of his work while Creative Director of ACMI, and a discussion of specific works in the permanent collection of exemplary works.

results.title: Just desserts
results.brief_description: This wonderfully sensuous short presents the rites of puberty as a menu of Italian favourites: a young girls first period occurs when she is stomping the grapes; gnocchi is forever to remind her of first having sex with a boy; burnt polenta is the taste of lesbian longing. A lovely remembrance of an Italo-Australian adolescence.

results.title: Ross Gibson interview: tape #1
results.brief_description:
Interview Date: 21st March, 2002.
Ross Gibson takes the interviewers through the ACMI site discussing issues regarding the conception of the building, ideas and philosophies behind the interaction between the public and the space, working processes, anticipated audience experiences and, a general background of the history of the planning and construction of the Centre.

results.title: Chicks With Decks
results.brief_description: A documentary about teenage Australian girls with a love for skateboards and making rhymes. This student work features spectacular skateboarding footage.

results.title: Relative strangers
results.brief_description: A beautiful mediation on the meaning of family and blood ties. Photographs and home movies of the past form the extent of one man’s childhood memory of his father. In attempting to recover his past, he discovers that time’s absences and betrayals are apt to be repeated.

results.title: Joseph Schultz
results.brief_description: A young German soldier refuses to fire on a line of Yugoslav partisans. His disobedience costs him his life. Based on an actual event in the Second World War, Joseph Schultz uses both realistic reconstruction and documentary evidence to assert the continuing resonance of resistance.
